content.description: On the furthest left end of the boulder layback the large-fist crack from a crouch start.
Great moves throughout working up to a bulge and into a faint corner to a high top. Pure and engaging, maybe the best line on the bloc.
content.protection: Pads. More the better but the landing is perfectly flat.
content.location: Starts 1/3 of the way into "footless" goes straight up to a bulge and hanging corner on the tallest section of he bloc. The upper moves are directly right of the prominent tree. (A variant goes right at the bulge V7)

content.description:
Raging Bull has amazing movement, and, like everything else in Leavenworth, great rock. Start sitting with a good low left crimp, and a good right hand. It's a hollow sharp edge/crimp. At my height, I had half a thigh on the boulder beneath to start.

Paste your foot, and gun for the rad slopers. Stay tight, use your heels and toes, and move through a few more slopers, which will feel huge if you can keep your feet from cutting.

The only black eye on this one is the dab potential on the first move (careful with your right foot!), and I could see how the line could turn off some people because the hardest bit is getting off the ground.

Persevere! And send me a message if you can't find the secret micro foot. Top out on the big sloping ledge above, and jump/climb down onto your pad.

A really great little problem, with a perfect name.

This thing is a true classic. Great movement.
content.protection:
One pad.

If you have an ego that requires stroking, you could climb to the top of the boulder. This is not enthusiastically recommended. I'm not the Leavenworth Bouldering Police, but I'd say once you've topped out on the big ledge at eight feet, you've done the problem. You are now a Raging Bull.
content.location: There's kind of a softly jutting-out corner on the Footless Traverse. Right of it is Big Booty Bitch Slap, v10. Left and low under the roof, you'll find Raging Bull. Look for the well-chalked low starting holds, and the v-slot you're shooting for on the first move.

content.description: Start on the big right-facing jug-sidepull as for Footless Traverse. Move up to slopers, then move right into the middle of Lion of Judah. It has the same amount of moves but it's less powerful, less reachy, and more tension-y at the start.
content.protection: Preferably 6+. I did it with 3.5 but not recommended.

content.description: A super cool line on the right side of the footless bloc. Big moves, steep and airy feeling, with an in your face mantle into a slab at the 15' level. A proud line on perfect stone.
content.protection: Pads. The landing area for the high crux slopes away so use spotters or get creative with pad management.
content.location: About 6' right of "footless" start on two high crimps. Head up through slopers, side-pull in a bulge, and a nice jug before the finishing heady mantle onto the hanging slab. Full-value.

content.description: A nice extension to Raging Bull that adds several traversing moves at the start and improves the overall flow.  Adds a couple grades of difficulty but still shares the crux of the former route.  Be careful not to dab the rock when transitioning into the right heel hook crux.
content.location: Starts underneath the Footless Traverse at the low point of the overhang with a good right hand jug and a crossed over left hand.  Traverse left into Raging Bull.

content.description: This problem starts on a right facing jug block looking towards the road. From here you traverse left through 3 distinct sections. You start on crimps, move to a campus-y section and then power your way through the ending section to a hidden jug about midway into the boulder. There are feet, but you have to think critically to find them. Throw to the jug in the middle of the boulder and do an awkward and squished mantle to finish this problem or if you're feeling spicy, top out the boulder. Topping out doesn't add much and it's mostly just a flex.
content.protection: As many pads as you can bring or one really good spotter who will move a pad for you through the problem. It's low to the ground but it's very long from right to left.
content.location: 50 YDS from the picnic area, via a short hike by the areas' other problems, or a short scramble right below the Campus Traverse area.

content.description:
Guidebook says traverse left to the crack along the shelf, but can also sit start below the obvious "Wide Boyz" style crack and follow it to the top at the same rating (if your here, it's obviously because of the crack).

North facing, cool in the summer.
content.location: Climber's left side of Footless Traverse boulder, can't miss it.

content.description: Climb the super steep and dirty slab using either arete. The right arete has a stump right by it and is easier but with a sketchy landing (the stump is on). V3/4 for the left arete depending on height, V3 for the right arete, and VHard if you try to go straight up the face...
content.protection: 1 pad for the left arete, or 1.5 pad and a good spotter for the right. The .5 pad is for the stump
content.location: There is a small boulder about 8 feet behind the Campus traverse boulder with this one problem on it. It is right next to the top of the steep hill that goes down to the road.
